Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision

Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to RPD decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence was ignored; applicants failed to produce evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Clear and unequivocal evidence required for denial of justice
Crimes.Application_Factor: Delay in reporting incidents and reliance on legal advice
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of judicial review application
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation in border documentation

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and burden of proof on applicant
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lawyer provided technically correct advice but no formal complaint filed

Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not directly applicable, but omission constitutes false statement by implication

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants’ account not sufficiently corroborated
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: N/A – matter related to immigration assessment, not criminal sentencing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96-97; Criminal Code provisions on threats (s. 264)

Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 117(9)(d) excludes family members not examined during sponsor’s permanent residence process

Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent met the residence requirements under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act

Basis_of_Claim: Alleged failure to meet Canadian citizenship residency requirements
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient evidence of physical presence and lack of clarity in judicial reasoning
Proceeding_Type: Appeal under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Error: Failure to specify which residency test was applied and inadequate justification
Assessment_Standard: Three judicial approaches: strict physical presence, strong attachment to Canada, or place of centralized existence

Application_Factor: Duration and quality of physical presence in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a new citizenship judge

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion order upheld initially, later quashed on judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Procedural Fairness Breach under Administrative Law
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of administrative decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Denial of procedural fairness to unrepresented party
Crimes.Governing_Law: Administrative law principles, Charter-adjacent procedural rights
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to allow respondent to present evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision set aside, costs awarded to applicant
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show breach of natural justice
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Administrative bodies must ensure fair hearing for all, especially unrepresented parties
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Presiding member failed to assist unrepresented litigant
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Remitted for redetermination by new panel
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Record of IAD hearing and conduct of presiding member
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Principles of natural justice and procedural fairness
Crimes.Defendant_Response: IAD upheld exclusion order without adequate process
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of decision, costs
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, decision quashed, costs awarded
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Principles derived from common law and administrative law jurisprudence

Risk_Type: Risk due to state protection failure

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Risk_Nature: Failure of legal system to intervene

Burden_of_Proof: On applicant, but not properly evaluated
Legal_Rule: Child vulnerabilities must be considered under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Necessities of Life
Defendant_Response: Board relied on general country conditions

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status exclusion under international convention
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity in crimes against peace through military service
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, Article 1F(a) of the 1951 Refugee Convention

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status exclusion based on alleged complicity in war crimes
Crimes.Outcome: Board's decision set aside due to lack of evidence
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Service in Colombian army accused of war crimes
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International humanitarian law, Article 1F(a) of the 1951 Refugee Convention

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection over alleged complicity
Crimes.Outcome: Decision overturned; case remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Indirect association with army committing isolated atrocities
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International human rights law, Article 1F(a) of the 1951 Refugee Convention

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship revocation based on fraudulent conduct by parent
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can citizenship obtained by minors through a parent's fraudulent actions be revoked under sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Rim Sawaf admitted to using an immigration consultant but failed to disclose it; credibility of her intent is disputed
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Admission of use of immigration consultant, application records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False representation or fraud by parent (Rim Sawaf) in citizenship application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Whether omission of immigration consultant constitutes false representation or fraud
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose use of immigration consultant
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Genuine issue for trial exists regarding material facts
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Revocation allowed if citizenship obtained by false representation, fraud, or concealment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Minor status of applicants at time of application
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Trial required to resolve factual disputes
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Summary judgment standard – genuine issue for trial
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Potential misrepresentation in citizenship application form due to nondisclosure

Crimes.Crime_Name: Knowingly concealing material circumstances in citizenship application
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship revocation based on parent's concealment of material information
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can citizenship obtained by minors be revoked if the parent made false representations or knowingly concealed material circumstances, regardless of the minor's knowledge?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Rim Sawaf’s intent and knowledge in omitting consultant use are in question
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Admission of consultant use, citizenship application documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Parent’s failure to disclose use of immigration consultant as material circumstance
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Whether non-disclosure constitutes knowingly concealing material circumstances
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission of immigration consultant in application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Existence of genuine issue for trial on material facts
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Revocation permissible for false representation, fraud, or concealment under the Act
Crimes.Application_Factor: Minors’ lack of knowledge about parent’s actions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Trial necessary to assess mother’s conduct and its legal consequences
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Summary judgment standard – genuine issue for trial
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Incomplete or inaccurate citizenship application due to nondisclosure

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Revocation of citizenship based on false representation by parent during application process
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is obtaining citizenship by false representation or fraud under sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act applicable to minors who had no knowledge of their parents' actions?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Rim Sawaf’s intent in not disclosing immigration consultant is contested
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Admission of third-party involvement, application forms
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged false representation by mother in securing citizenship for children
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Impact of parent’s false representation on validity of minors’ citizenship
Crimes.Application_Error: Non-disclosure of immigration consultant involvement
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Presence of genuine factual dispute requiring trial
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Citizenship may be revoked if obtained by false representation, fraud, or concealment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Minor applicants’ unawareness of parental misconduct
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial of summary judgment; case proceeds to trial
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Summary judgment standard – genuine issue for trial
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Potential falsity in application due to incomplete disclosure

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in making implausibility and negative credibility findings
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; case remanded for reconsideration
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding based on assumptions rather than evidence
Evidence_Type: Applicant's testimony, explanations regarding persecution and flight
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution due to religious affiliation and activities in Pakistan
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to claim asylum in the U.S., attackers' failure to kill, applicant's profile as a target
Application_Error: Reliance on unsupported assumptions and unreasonable inferences
Evidence_Ignored: Plausible explanations provided by the applicant
Application_Factor: Personal risk, flight path, consistency of narrative

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 68(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ferri, a permanent resident, was convicted of a narcotics offense, triggering automatic cancellation of his deportation stay under s. 68(4)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Constitutional challenge to s. 68(4) raised during appeal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD has jurisdiction to hear constitutional challenges under s. 68(4)
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction record, IRPA provisions, Charter arguments
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacks jurisdiction to consider constitutionality of s. 68(4)
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of deportation and hearing of constitutional challenge
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of IRPA sections 162(1) and 68(4)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Explicit statutory language of s. 68(4) limits IAD’s role to factual determinations, overriding general jurisdiction under s. 162(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Deportation order under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Constitutionality of deportation provisions in immigration law
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order upheld due to lack of IAD jurisdiction over constitutional issues
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of Charter rights due to denial of appeal rights after second serious offense
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Cancellation of deportation stay and termination of appeal
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Permanent resident seeking protection from deportation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of heroin for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Criminal prosecution and immigration consequences
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Jurisdiction of IAD to hear constitutional challenges under s. 68(4) IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Criminal Code of Canada, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Appeal before IAD and subsequent judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for possession of heroin for trafficking used as basis for deportation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed constitutional challenge; Federal Court upheld decision
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate IAD jurisdiction
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 68(4) IRPA removes IAD's ability to stay deportation upon second serious offense
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Charter challenge to s. 68(4) IRPA based on fairness and right to appeal
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Constitutional challenge not heard; deportation process resumed
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Ferri argued that s. 68(4) violates Charter rights
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of deportation and constitutional review by IAD
Crimes.Outcome: Remedy denied due to statutory bar on IAD jurisdiction

Violation_Type: Refusal of protection based on risk assessment
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - Protection obligations
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution in Turkey due to Kurdish ethnicity and political activities; PRRA officer assessed new evidence including a lawyer's letter and country reports
Claimant_Status: Protected Person or Applicant for Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA)
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistency in applicant's evidence regarding arrests and involvement
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer may have unreasonably dismissed key evidence (lawyer's letter on 1998 arrest)
Evidence_Used: Lawyer's letter confirming 1998 arrest, UK country report on treatment of activist Kurds, applicant's statements on political involvement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA officer found applicant's evidence unpersuasive; lack of corroboration on arrest claims
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility questioned regarding past arrests and level of political activism
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; decision upheld despite error on one factual finding
Relief_Sought: Protection under PRRA due to risk of persecution, torture, or cruel and unusual treatment
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and referral back for re-determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the PRRA officer's decision was reasonable under the standard of reasonableness
Decision_Rationale: Even if the finding on the 1998 arrest was unreasonable, the overall conclusion stands as arrests alone do not constitute persecution; country evidence indicates harassment but not systematic persecution

Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Diallo would face unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship if required to apply for permanent residence from Guinea
Procedural_Stage: Judicial Review of H&C Application Decision
Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in application, lack of personalized risk evidence, establishment in Canada
Decision_Outcome: H&C application denied; judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must prove unusual hardship beyond normal immigration requirements
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in Mr. Diallo's application affected credibility
Legal_Rule: Applicant must demonstrate exceptional circumstances causing unusual hardship not anticipated by the Immigration Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Hardship due to conditions in Guinea and establishment in Canada
Outcome_on_Merits: No exceptional hardship found; officer's decision upheld
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conditions in Guinea, applicant's ties to Canada, inconsistencies in testimony
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds under IRPA
Defendant_Response: Officer concluded no exceptional hardship based on lack of evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal claims, country condition reports
Remedy_Requested: Permanent residence in Canada on H&C grounds
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Mr. Diallo must apply for permanent residence from Guinea
Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration appeal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD can consider H&C grounds if the applicant is no longer a member of the family class at the time of the hearing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant misrepresented criminal history
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Loss of family class membership due to separation
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Appeal before the Immigration Appeal Division (IAD)
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose criminal history and loss of genuine relationship
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of IAD's interpretation of IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Jurisdictional requirement under s.65
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing of family class membership assessment
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacked jurisdiction to consider H&C grounds
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in immigration documents regarding criminal history

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to foreign criminal conviction
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had a US drug conviction and was separated from sponsor
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timing of family class status assessment
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD's authority to hear H&C appeal without current family class status
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction record, sponsorship relationship evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant not credible due to non-disclosure
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacked jurisdiction; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on H&C grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Current membership in family class required at time of hearing

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose criminal history in permanent resident application
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration appeal involving misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether IAD must assess family class membership at the time of the hearing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked credibility due to concealment of conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Type: US criminal conviction record, application forms
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds despite misrepresentation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Loss of family class status due to separation and prior misrepresentation
Crimes.Application_Error: Non-disclosure of criminal history in PR application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable interpretation of statutory requirements
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Jurisdiction under IRPA s.65
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing of status assessment
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacked jurisdiction to consider H&C factors
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False statements in permanent resident application regarding criminal history

Crimes.Crime_Name: False representation or fraud in obtaining citizenship
Legal_Issue: Standing to challenge Governor in Council's decision
Governing_Law: Section 18.1(1) of the Federal Courts Act
Outcome: Appeal allowed, motion to strike dismissed
Basis_of_Claim: Improper discretion in not revoking citizenship
Application_Factor: Involvement in war crimes justice, representation of victims' relatives

Crimes.Crime_Name: Knowingly concealing material circumstances in obtaining citizenship
Violation_Type: Failure to disclose material facts in citizenship process
Application_Facts: Non-revocation of citizenship despite alleged concealment
Claimant_Status: League for Human Rights as applicant
Procedural_Issue: Motion to strike based on lack of standing
Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Governor in Council under Citizenship Act
Outcome: Judicial review proceeding to next stage
Decision_Rationale: Serious question, genuine interest, no alternative remedy

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Lin claimed refugee status due to fear of persecution for attending an underground Christian church in China.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application under s. 72 of the Act challenging the Board’s rejection of Lin’s refugee claim.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of documentary evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned credibility due to inconsistencies and lack of evidence; court found assessment reasonable.
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the Board's decision on judicial review
Decision_Rationale: The Board's decision was based on sufficient reasons including credibility concerns and lack of supporting documentation.

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Constitutional challenge to statutory term
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether 'subversion' is unconstitutionally vague under Section 7 of the Charter
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration Act, paragraph 19(1)(e), Charter of Rights and Freedoms (Sections 7, 2, 15)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Based on applicant's past involvement with PFLP
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Term 'subversion' not unconstitutionally vague
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate violation of Charter rights
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Involvement with PFLP assessed as credible basis for concern
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A law is unconstitutionally vague if it lacks precision and fails to guide legal debate or distinguish lawful from unlawful conduct
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed; use of 'subversion' justified under Section 1
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Charter analysis, proportionality, societal interests in national security
Crimes.Defendant_Response: National security justification for use of term 'subversion'
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial declaration that 'subversion' is unconstitutionally vague
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed in part; remitted for reconsideration by new panel
Crimes.Authority: Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Canadian administrative law principles

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization likely to engage in acts of violence
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Potential threat to national security through organizational affiliation
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Risk of engagement in subversive or violent activities
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Based on membership in PFLP, designated entity
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Past involvement with a known militant organization
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Subversive political activities involving potential violence
Crimes.Organization_Involved: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP)
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Supported by expert testimony and documentation
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliability and sufficiency of intelligence linking applicant to PFLP
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Intelligence reports, expert testimony, organizational records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Evidence deemed credible and sufficient for concern
Crimes.Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act framework
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Deportation based on security grounds

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Active participation in subversive actions against democratic states
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Individual engaged in anti-democratic activities via PFLP
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Continued allegiance or involvement with extremist group
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Political subversion, advocacy of violence, anti-state activities
Crimes.Organization_Involved: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP)
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Alleged active participation in subversive operations
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Assessed as credible based on available intelligence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Interpretation and weight of circumstantial evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Intelligence dossiers, organizational links, behavioral patterns
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Findings supported by coherent body of evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Corroboration across sources, consistency over time
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of security-based deportation recommendation
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Risk of removal from Canada on security grounds

Application_Facts: Applicants challenged Citizenship Officer's refusal of citizenship application for adopted daughter
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of breach of procedural fairness
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Officer's decision
Decision_Rationale: Decision based on total evidence; no key contradictory evidence ignored; third-party assistance did not affect decision-making

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution from FARC in Colombia
Procedural_Issue: Lack of oral hearing despite credibility being central to decision
Evidence_Used: Officer acknowledged FARC's human rights violations
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence provided by applicant to establish credibility
Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned applicant's credibility; credibility was central to the decision
Relief_Sought: Procedural fairness in pre-removal risk assessment
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness; reasonableness for fact-driven determinations
Decision_Rationale: Oral hearing required when credibility is at issue; absence constituted procedural error
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer conducting pre-removal risk assessment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Governance and authority conflict between Chief and councillors
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of court orders through misuse of official documents to remove Harley Frank as Chief
Crimes.Governing_Law: Indian Act and Amended Blood Tribe Custom Election Bylaws
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Contempt proceedings with court interventions, injunctions, and compliance enforcement
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inflammatory documents falsely attributed to Harley Frank were used without verification
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Defendants found in contempt for improper removal process
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to demonstrate violation of court orders
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Documents used were misleading and improperly sourced
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Due process required for tribal leadership removal; unauthorized actions prohibited
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Judicial review of compliance with court orders and procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized use of official processes and false documentation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Removal deemed invalid due to lack of due process
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Falsely attributed documents, court orders, procedural violations
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Tribal election bylaws and federal Indian Act provisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Proceeded with removal despite court injunctions
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, court filings, procedural records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Compliance with court orders and fair hearing
Crimes.Outcome: Contempt purged upon agreement to hold new elections
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Amended Blood Tribe Custom Election Bylaws; Indian Act
Crimes.Authority: Justices Muldoon, Teitelbaum, Joyal, and MacKay

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Conflict over tribal governance and leadership authority
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of court orders regarding Harley Frank's position as Chief
Crimes.Governing_Law: Contempt powers under common law and court procedural rules
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Contempt hearings following non-compliance with injunctions
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Defendants proceeded with unauthorized elections and removal actions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Defendants found in contempt but penalties avoided after compliance
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to prove willful disobedience of court orders
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Repeated defiance of judicial directives undermined court authority
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Contempt occurs when party disobeys or undermines court order
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Clear evidence of non-compliance with judicial orders
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized removal attempts, refusal to cooperate, holding illegal elections
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Contempt confirmed, but purged through corrective actions
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Court orders, motions, hearing transcripts, election records
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Court rules on contempt and injunctive relief
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Initially non-compliant, later agreed to general election
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Enforcement of court orders and cessation of unlawful actions
Crimes.Outcome: No penalties imposed after defendants held new election
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Inherent court power to punish for contempt
Crimes.Authority: Justices Muldoon, Teitelbaum, Joyal, and MacKay

Violation_Type: Failure to maintain permanent resident status
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.49(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant's appeal against removal order was ongoing; removal order not yet in effect; applicant failed to meet residency obligations
Residency_Compliance: No – failed to meet residency obligations
Procedural_Issue: No delay allowed under Citizenship Act s.14(1); citizenship application reviewed during pending removal appeal
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; citizenship judge's decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Reapplication permitted upon successful appeal of removal order
Legal_Standard_Applied: Eligibility under Citizenship Act s.5(1)(c) and (f)
Decision_Rationale: Applicant ineligible due to being under a removal order despite retaining permanent resident status during appeal

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of RPD decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in applying s. 109(1) and (2) of IRPA regarding misrepresentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 109(1) and (2)
Crimes.Outcome: RPD's decision set aside, new hearing ordered
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inadequate assessment of respondent's citizenship status
Crimes.Evidence_Type: New evidence related to Russian citizenship
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation of Russian citizenship status
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Improper consideration of new evidence under s. 109(2)
Crimes.Application_Error: RPD improperly considered new evidence under s. 109(2)
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether decision was based on material misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictions in citizenship status not adequately addressed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and extent of misrepresentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision overturned, new hearing required
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False representation of citizenship in immigration documents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of RPD decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in considering new evidence under s. 109(2) of IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 109(1) and (2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Improper consideration of new evidence on citizenship
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside, new hearing ordered
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Minister to prove misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 109(2) prohibits reassessing old evidence with new evidence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of RPD decision on citizenship misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether RPD erred in applying s. 109(1) and (2) of IRPA regarding fraud in obtaining documents
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 109(1) and (2)
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, new hearing ordered
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Failure to properly assess credibility of citizenship claims
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation of Russian citizenship to obtain immigration benefits
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of fraudulent information in document acquisition
Crimes.Application_Error: Considering new evidence under s. 109(2)
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Materiality of misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Impact of misrepresentation on refugee status eligibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Overturned, remitted for new hearing
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Acquisition of immigration documents through false citizenship claims

Application_Facts: Applicant must accumulate at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within four years preceding application; Mr. Haj-Kamali's absences were miscalculated by up to 136 days
Residency_Compliance: Alleged insufficient physical presence; calculation error and legal test ambiguity identified
Procedural_Issue: Miscalculation of absences, ambiguous application of legal test (physical presence vs. centralized mode of existence)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate calculation of absence days, lack of clarity in interpreting residency
Decision_Outcome: Denial of citizenship application due to insufficient residency
Outcome: Remitted to Citizenship Court for redetermination
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application with correct factual and legal assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act – 1,095-day residency requirement
Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness (factual findings), Reasonableness simpliciter (mixed fact and law)
Decision_Rationale: Potential factual error in calculating absences and unclear legal standard may have affected outcome

Crimes.Crime_Name: Excessive use of force by peace officer
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Civil rights violation, excessive force claim
Crimes.Outcome: Action dismissed; no excessive force found
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged physical harm during cell extraction, including multiple strikes and partial undressing
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Crown Liability and Proceedings Act, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Plaintiff failed to prove excessive force or causation of injury
Crimes.Protected_Group: Prisoners (as a vulnerable group under state care)
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Officers acted within legal authority; state protection deemed adequate
Crimes.Credibility: Conflicting witness testimonies; medical evidence inconclusive
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s.25 Criminal Code (use of force by peace officers)
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Found adequate; actions justified under law
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Use of physical force in custodial setting

Crimes.Crime_Name: Cruel and unusual treatment under Charter s.12
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Constitutional challenge to prison conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether strip cell confinement amounted to cruel and unusual punishment
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 12 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Trial stage with full evidentiary hearing
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff refused showers and exercise; conditions not shown to be degrading
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No violation of s.12 Charter rights
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to show treatment outraged standards of decency
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff's own behavior limited impact of deprivation claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Treatment must outrage standards of decency to breach s.12
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Prolonged strip cell confinement without normal privileges
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Witness testimony, medical reports, inmate behavior logs
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Confinement justified for safety and security

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Duration of confinement (two and a half months), lack of hygiene products
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Behavioral concerns justifying monitoring, refusal of privileges by inmate
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to prolonged isolation
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Administrative segregation without formal justification argued
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient – issue not raised in argument
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plaintiff’s claim not fully tested due to lack of argument
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – civil case, no conviction
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Common law tort of false imprisonment

Crimes.Location_of_Incident: Inside prison cell at Saskatchewan Penitentiary
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of force during cell extraction, allegations of repeated striking
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Plaintiff resisted, force applied in controlled environment
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Not relevant – focus on state actor conduct
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Medium – alleged physical harm but unproven
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Medical evidence did not confirm injury causation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plaintiff's account contradicted by official records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Crown Liability and Proceedings Act, s.25 Criminal Code

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 97(1)
Application_Facts: Maria Elena Solis Castillo claimed refugee status due to domestic violence by her partner in Costa Rica; submitted evidence indicated limited state protection for domestic violence victims.
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to address key evidence on state protection for domestic violence victims
Evidence_Used: Evidence showing limited police and judicial support for domestic violence victims in Costa Rica
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD did not explain why it dismissed or disregarded critical evidence on state protection
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially denied by RPD based on presumed state protection
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of claim with proper analysis of evidence
Decision_Rationale: RPD must provide adequate reasoning when dismissing central evidence, particularly on issues like state protection; failure to do so renders decision unreasonable
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Immigration and Refugee Board

Legal_Issue: Did the Appeal Board err in failing to place Rosemary Haney on the eligibility list after finding her qualified?
Evidence_Assessment: Eligibility list expiration, pass mark validity, candidate qualifications
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate error in selection process
Credibility_Factor: Perceived bias and procedural irregularities in selection process
Legal_Rule: Commission must select highest-ranking qualified candidates for eligibility lists under s. 17(1)
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural errors, improper application of pass mark, failure to update eligibility list
Outcome_on_Merits: Appeal Board erred in narrow interpretation of jurisdiction
Key_Evidence_Considered: Revised pass mark rendering Haney qualified, expired eligibility list
Legal_Framework: Public Service Employment Act, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Appeal Board cited expired list and limited jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, correction of eligibility list
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded to new Appeal Board
Legal_Provision: s. 17(1) of the Public Service Employment Act
Authority: Federal Court or equivalent reviewing tribunal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Disclose Absences from Canada
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship eligibility dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge unreasonably assessed evidence, credibility, and applied the qualitative residence test
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Judge failed to rigorously analyze contradictory evidence on lifestyle and absences
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Residence requirements under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Undeclared absences and misrepresentation concerns
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Split lifestyle between countries and unverified absences
Crimes.Application_Error: Speculative assumptions about absence durations
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Qualitative residence test (centralized mode of existence)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant's physical presence and ties to Canada
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted to the Minister for reassessment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship eligibility dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in failing to consider the undisclosed passport affecting credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Incomplete evaluation of 'VIOPP' entry indicating another passport
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted to the Minister for redetermination
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with residency and honesty
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Obligation to disclose all relevant facts affecting credibility
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: 'VIOPP' notation in file suggesting foreign passport
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian citizenship law and procedural fairness
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No explanation provided for the 'VIOPP' entry
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of Citizenship Act related to misrepresentation and credibility

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship eligibility dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge unreasonably assessed evidence and residency requirements
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Judge inadequately analyzed split life between countries
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Residency and good faith application requirements
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation in residence claims
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of justification for assumed absence durations
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to investigate discrepancies in financial activity
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictory credit card transactions during claimed Canadian residence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Physical presence or centralized mode of existence test
Crimes.Application_Factor: Residency compliance and truthful disclosure
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted to the Minister for reevaluation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspected false statements in application

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship eligibility dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge unreasonably assessed credit card evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rules of evidence and credibility in administrative decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient scrutiny of international credit card transactions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted to the Minister for reevaluation
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove continuous residence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Unverified use of credit card by daughter; U.S. transactions during Canadian residence claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Requirement to reasonably engage with all material evidence
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Inadequate investigation into financial behavior contradicting residence claims
Key_Evidence_Considered: U.S. transactions during claimed Canadian presence
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law standards in citizenship adjudication
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed daughter used card; no verification provided
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Implied duty of honest and complete disclosure in applications

Violation_Type: Denial of humanitarian and compassionate application for permanent residency
Application_Facts: Officer assessed hardship as 'unique' (analogous to 'unusual' or 'disproportionate'), balanced economic hardship and family separation against reunification with paternal relatives
Procedural_Issue: Allegation that officer required 'unique' hardship and failed to consider best interests of children
Evidence_Used: Existing application record; no new evidence presented
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No new evidence submitted to support reconsideration
Decision_Outcome: Application for permanent residence denied on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the immigration officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under s. 114(2)
Decision_Rationale: Officer did not fetter discretion; interpretation of 'unique' hardship was reasonable; best interests of children were implicitly considered within the overall assessment

Crimes.Crime_Name: Acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations
Risk_Factor: alleged complicity in crimes by the Haitian National Police
Admission_or_Involvement: Kenny Merceron was a Haitian police officer during alleged abuses
Evidence_Credibility: insufficient evidence linking Merceron directly to crimes
Key_Evidence_Issue: mere membership does not equate to complicity without active participation
Credibility_Assessment: RPD erred by inferring complicity without evidence
Standard_of_Proof: reviewable error due to lack of sufficient evidence
Governing_Provision: Article 1F(a) and 1F(c) of the Refugee Convention
Consequences_of_Action: refugee claim denied, judicial review granted, case remitted

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: exclusion from refugee protection based on alleged complicity
Legal_Framework: Article 1F(a) and 1F(c) of the Refugee Convention
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside, case remitted for reconsideration
Risk_Factor: alleged complicity in systematic abuses by Haitian National Police
Credibility: knowledge of crimes insufficient to prove complicity
Risk_Nature: crimes against humanity as widespread or systematic attacks
